text: 2.1  NUMBER:  Students use numbers in everyday and mathematical contexts to quantify or describe phenomena, develop concepts of operations with different types of numbers, use the structure and properties of numbers with operations to solve problems, and perform mathematical computations.  Students develop number sense related to magnitude, estimation, and the effects of mathematical operations on different types of numbers. It is expected that students use numbers flexibly, using forms of numbers that best match a situation.  Students compute efficiently and accurately.  Estimation should always be used when computing with numbers or solving problems.

children.text: Whole Number
Students understand and use number notation and place value to 10,000 in numerals.
Students understand and use procedures to add and subtract whole numbers with up to four digits.
Students understand and apply meanings of multiplication and division.
Students understand and use number notation and place value to 100,000 in numerals.
Students understand and use the concepts of factor and multiple.
Students understand and use procedures to multiply and divide whole numbers by two-digit numbers.
Students understand and use number notation to 10 million in numerals and words.
Students multiply and divide numbers up to four digits by numbers up to 2 digits, and by tens, hundreds, and thousands and interpret any remainders.
Students solve problems requiring multiple operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division) and use the conventions of order of operations (no exponents expected).
Students use factors and multiples.
Rational Number
Students recognize, name, compare, illustrate, and use simple fractions.
Students understand, name, compare, illustrate, combine, and use fractions.
Students understand and use number notation and place value in numbers with two decimal places in real world contexts including money.
Students understand, name, compare, illustrate, compute with, and use fractions.
Students understand and use number notation and place value in numbers with three decimal places.
Students understand concepts of positive and negative integers.
Students express fractions greater than 0 as decimals and compare positive numbers that are written as fractions and decimals and place them on the number line.
Students add, subtract, multiply, and divide numbers expressed as fractions and as decimals including mixed numbers.
Students understand how to express relative quantities as percentages and as decimals and fractions.
Students multiply and divide decimals with up to three decimal places by tens, hundreds, and thousands.
Students use negative and positive rational numbers expressed as integers, fractions, and decimals.
Students compute with signed rational numbers.
Students understand that when the ratio of two varying quantities is constant, the two quantities are in direct proportion.
Students interpret and use percents to solve problems.
Students express or interpret numbers using scientific notation from real-life contexts.
Real Number
Students understand the set of real numbers as containing the rational numbers and the irrational numbers.
Students know how to represent and use real numbers.

text:
2.2 DATA: Students make measurements and collect, display, evaluate, analyze, and compute with data to describe or model phenomena and to make decisions based on data. Students compute statistics to summarize data sets and use concepts of probability to make predictions and describe the uncertainty inherent in data collection and measurement. It is expected that when working with measurements students:
  • understand that most measurements are approximations and that taking repeated measurements reveals this variability;
  • understand that a number without a unit is not a measurement, and that an appropriate unit must always be attached to a number to provide a measurement;
  • understand that the precision and accuracy of a measurement depends on selecting the appropriate tools and units; and
  • use estimation comparing measures to benchmarks appropriate to the type of measure and units.

children.text: Measurement and Approximation
Students understand and use measurement of time and temperature.
Students understand and use measurement of time, capacity, and temperature.
Students understand and use measures of elapsed time, temperature, capacity, and mass and use measures of mass and weight.
Students convert within measurement systems.
Students understand and use derived measures (measurements expressed as rates).
Students convert across measurement systems and within a system for different units in derived measures.
Students understand the relationship between precision and accuracy.
Data Analysis
Students read, construct, and interpret bar graphs.
Students collect and represent data in tables, line plots, and bar graphs, and read and interpret these types of data displays.
Students read, construct, and interpret line graphs.
Students find and use median, mode, and range for a set of data.
Students read and interpret pie charts.
Students find and compare the mean, median, mode, and range for sets of data.
Students use graphs and charts to represent, organize, interpret, and draw inferences from data.
Students use the mean, median, mode, range, and quartiles to solve problems involving raw data and information from data displays.
Students understand correlation and cause and effect.
Students understand and know how to describe distributions and find and use descriptive statistics for a set of data.
Students understand that the purpose of random sampling is to reduce bias when creating a representative sample for a set of data.
Probability
Students understand and apply concepts of probability to simple events.
Students understand and apply concepts of probability.
Students understand the relationship of probability to relative frequency and know how to find the probability of compound events.

text: 2.3 GEOMETRY:  Students use measurement and observation to describe objects based on their sizes and shapes; model or construct two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects; solve problems involving geometric properties; compute areas and volumes based on object properties and dimensions; and perform transformations on geometric figures.  When making or calculating measures students use estimation to check the reasonableness of results.

children.text: Geometric Figures
Students identify, describe, and classify familiar two-dimensional shapes.
Students identify and name angles, lines, relationships between lines, quadrilaterals, and triangles.
Students identify, describe, and classify solid figures.
Students represent solid figures in two dimensions.
Students understand angle properties of lines in the plane.
Students know and use properties of polygons.
Students know and use angle properties of parallel lines to solve problems and determine geometric relationships.
Students know and use the Pythagorean Theorem.
Students justify statements about polygons and solve problems.
Students justify statements about circles and solve problems.
Students understand and use basic ideas of trigonometry.
Geometric Measurement
Students understand how to find the distance around a figure.
Students understand the concept of area of a figure.
Students find the area of triangles and quadrilaterals.
Students understand how to find the volume and surface area of rectangular prisms.
Students understand how to describe position and direction in two dimensions.
Students find the perimeters and areas of geometric figures.
Students find the volume and surface areas of right prisms with bases that are triangles and quadrilaterals.
Students solve problems involving perimeter and area.
Students find the volume and surface area of prisms, pyramids, cylinders, and other figures composed of these solids.
Students find the surface area and volume of three-dimensional objects.
Transformations
Students recognize congruent figures and line symmetry in figures.
Students reflect, slide, and rotate plane figures.
Students understand and use reflections, rotations, and translations to define and identify congruent plane figures.
Students understand how to use proportional relationships to make indirect linear measurements and use scale drawings to make linear measurements.
Students understand and use the concept of scale drawings to enlarge or reduce two dimensional plane figures.

text: 2.4 ALGEBRA: Students use symbols to represent or model quantities, patterns, and relationships and use symbolic manipulation to evaluate expressions and solve equations.  Students solve problems using symbols, tables, graphs, and verbal rules choosing the most effective representation and converting among representations.

children.text: Symbols and Expressions
Students use equivalent expressions to aid computation such as knowing that 43 + 56 is the same as 40 + 3 + 50 + 6.
Students create and evaluate simple expressions in the context of numbers and operations as described in Standard 2.1: Number for this grade level.
Students create and evaluate simple expressions in the context of numbers and operations as described in Standard 2.1: Number for this grade level.
Students create and evaluate expressions.
Students create and evaluate expressions.
Students create, evaluate, and manipulate expressions.
Students understand and use polynomials and expressions with rational exponents.
Equations and Inequalities

Students find the unknown in simple equations (or open sentences) in the context of numbers and operations as described in Standard 2.1: Number for this grade level such as:
    3 + 5 = [ ] + 3
    3 + 9 = [ ] + 10
    [ ] + ( ) = 10

Students find the unknown in simple equations in the context of numbers and operations as described in Standard 2.1: Number for this grade level such as:
    3 · b = 12
    3 + 4 = x + 5
    6 x 5 = 3 x [ ]

Students find the unknown in simple equations in the context of numbers and operations as described in Standard 2.1: Number for this grade level such as:
    39 – k = 39 – 40
    78 + b = 57 + 79
    30 x A = 276
    (3 + 4) x 6 = 6 x [ ]
    3 x 15 = 3 x (10 + [ ])
Students recognize and solve problems involving linear equations and recognize examples and non-examples of linear equations.
Students understand and solve problems involving linear equations and know that a linear equation can be written in the form 0 = ax + b.
Students understand and solve problems involving linear equations.
Students understand and solve linear inequalities in one unknown.
Students solve families of equations and inequalities.
Students understand and apply ideas of logarithms.
Functions and Relations
Students understand arithmetic relationships among positive whole numbers.
Students create, describe, explain, and extend patterns with numbers and geometric objects.
Students use tables, rules, diagrams, and patterns to represent the relationship between quantities and to extend sequences.
Students use tables, rules, diagrams, and graphs to represent and analyze the relationship between quantities.
Students use tables, formulas, diagrams, and graphs to analyze relationships between quantities.
Students understand and use directly proportional relationships, y = kx.
Students understand and use the basic properties of linear relationships, y = kx+ b.
Students understand and interpret the characteristics of functions using graphs, tables, and algebraic techniques.
Students express relationships recursively and use iterative methods to solve problems.
